qas.question: What darkens a conventional bulb over its lifetime?

answers.text: the evaporated tungsten eventually condenses on the inner surface of the glass envelope

qas.question: What is the IEC guideline for an unacceptable level of light loss?

answers.text: An incandescent lamp that gives 93% or less of its initial light output at 75% of its rated life is regarded as unsatisfactory

qas.question: What are the primary causes of light loss?

answers.text: Light loss is due to filament evaporation and bulb blackening

qas.question: Where in the bulb is evaporated tungsten deposited when inert gas is used?

answers.text: on the uppermost part of the envelope

qas.question: Where in the bulb is evaporated tungsten deposited when a vacuum is used?

answers.text: across the entire surface of the envelope

plausible_answers.text: the evaporated tungsten eventually condenses on the inner surface of the glass envelope
the darkening is uniform across the entire surface of the envelope

qas.question: What happens when bulbs do not contain a vacuum?

plausible_answers.text: An incandescent lamp that gives 93% or less of its initial light output at 75% of its rated life is regarded as unsatisfactory

qas.question: What is the IEC guidelines for acceptable level of light loss?
What does not cause light loss or bulb blackening?

context: In a conventional lamp, <a0_0><b5_0>the evaporated tungsten eventually condenses on the inner surface of the glass envelope<b5_0/><a0_0/>, darkening it. For bulbs that contain a vacuum, <b6_0>the darkening is uniform <a4_0>across the entire surface of the envelope<b6_0/><a4_0/>. When a filling of inert gas is used, the evaporated tungsten is carried in the thermal convection currents of the gas, depositing preferentially <a3_0>on the uppermost part of the envelope<a3_0/> and blackening just that portion of the envelope. <a1_0><b7_0>An incandescent lamp that gives 93% or less of its initial light output at 75% of its rated life is regarded as unsatisfactory<b7_0/><a1_0/>, when tested according to IEC Publication 60064. <a2_0>Light loss is due to <b8_0>filament evaporation<b8_0/> and bulb blackening<a2_0/>. Study of the problem of bulb blackening led to the discovery of the Edison effect, thermionic emission and invention of the vacuum tube.
